Award.AbstractNarration: The Principal Investigator and collaborators will carry out an observational program to obtain very high resolution imaging of main belt, near-Earth, and Trojan asteroids, using adaptive optics (AO) systems on 8- and 10-meter telescopes. The objectives of this program are to (1) search for binary asteroids and obtain orbits for newly discovered and known binaries; and to (2) obtain sizes, shapes, albedos, and rotation poles (spin axis directions) for roughly 25 large main-belt asteroids through repeated imaging that resolves the objects themselves. They will also coordinate and carry out observations of stellar occultation events, and use software that they have developed to simultaneously fit the imaging, occultation, and available light-curve data. By pushing the current limits of adaptive optics, this work will contribute to improvement of AO technology. The investigators will also endeavor to include non-professional astronomers in their occultation observations, and will conduct outreach activities including public presentations and preparation of exhibit materials for the Onizuka Science Center in Kona, Hawaii.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of our program was to acquire images of asteroids with
astounding clarity using some of the world's largest telescopes.  The
use of large telescopes (larger mirror sizes) benefits us in two ways:
1) the larger the mirror, the sharper are the pictures that we can
acquire, and 2) the larger the mirror, the more light can be gathered
from any particular source and this means we can look at fainter
objects than with a smaller mirror.

The goals of our program were 1) to search for moons around
asteroids, and 2) with the sharp images, we can determine
the size and shape of the asteroids themselves.

We use a relatively new technology on these large telescopes
called "adaptive optics" or AO.   This technique effectively
detects the distortion in an image caused by the Earth's
atmosphere, and then tries to restore the image to what
it would look like without the atmosphere.  It does this
by using the equivalent of a "fun house" mirror to remove
these distortions.  The result is an image that is as sharp
as some space-based telescopes, but without the
high cost of a space telescope.  We can also make use
of larger mirrors than can be placed in space, giving yet
sharper images, as described above.`

Why do we want to study asteorids?

First, asteroids represent relatively primitive bodies that
have been unaltered, for the most part, by processes
that affect major planets, such as weather or volcanic or
tectonic processes.  That means that they may still
retain hints of the early solar system and contain information
about how our solar system formed.  The main process
that affects asteroids is collisions among asteroids.  Collisions
between asteroids and the surfaces of planets or the Moon
have also occurred over the billions of years since the
birth of the solar system.   We see evidence of this
process in the craters left on the surface of Earth's moon.
Most, but not all, such craters on Earth have been
erased by weather and geological processes. 

Thus, we know that collisions have played a critical
role not only in the evolution of asteroids, but also
in the histories of the planets, including Earth.  And
collisions are still important when we consider the
hazards that impacts by asteroids may still pose to
life on Earth.

How can searching for asteroid moons help us understand
asteroids and collisions?

Partly due to our program, we know that asteroid moons
can exist and that they can take many forms and are around
many types of asteroids.  Many of these moons were formed
by collisions.   Collisions can be modeled by computer
programs and may be studied on small scales in laboratories.
But nothing of the scale of asteroids (some hundreds of miles
across) can be esimulated in any lab.  So these moons give
us a giant real-life laboratory to study collisions by asteroids,
how they may affect Earth, and how dangerous they may
be to Earth.

How can determining size and shape of an asteroid help
us understand asteroids and collisions?

Asteroids that have been hit by other asteroids may retain
markings (giant craters) that are remnants of the impacts
such as those on the Moon.  Unlike the Moon, however,

gouges or facets.  We can detect these and try to
understand the history of impacts.
